docs.lead_paragraph: Inmates are taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.

headline.main: Little-Known Health Act Fact: Prison Inmates Are Signing Up
headline.print_headline: Little-Known Health Act Fact: Prison Inmates Are Signing Up

docs.abstract: Jails and prisons around country are beginning to sign up inmates for health insurance, taking advantage of little-known aspect of the Affordable Care Act that allows states to expand Medicaid coverage to single and childless adults; those who gain coverage in prison will also have it after they get out, key improvement for group that suffers from disproportionately high rates of chronic disease.
docs.snippet: Inmates are taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.

docs.lead_paragraph: The local Chinese official remembers the panic he felt in Room 109. He had refused to confess to bribery he says he didn't commit, and his Communist Party interrogators were forcing his legs apart.

headline.main: In China, Brutality Yields Confessions of Graft
headline.print_headline: In China, Brutality Yields Confessions of Graft

docs.snippet: The local Chinese official remembers the panic he felt in Room 109. He had refused to confess to bribery he says he didn't commit, and his Communist Party interrogators were forcing his legs apart.

docs.lead_paragraph: The local Chinese official remembers all too clearly the panic he felt in Room 109. He had refused again and again to confess to bribery he says he didn't commit, and his four Communist Party interrogators were forcing his legs farther apart than they could go.

headline.main: In China, Brutality Yields Confessions of Graft

docs.lead_paragraph: Over cocktails and chocolate-covered strawberries, a group of west Michigan Republicans gathered at a Tudor-style home in Grand Rapids and vented frustrations with Congressman Justin Amash and his Tea Party tactics that they blame for Washington's gridlock.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOYMAN--Scott. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, labor leader. At 93, Scott passed away after a long battle with Alzheimer's. A graduate of Monmouth College, IL, Scott became aware of the labor movement while living in Philadelphia and attending the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He began working for the Textile Workers Union of America (TWUA) in New England, but spent most of his career as the Southern Regional Director for the TWUA. Later he became head of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union's (ACTWU) textile division. Dedicated to social justice and racial equality, Scott worked tirelessly to organize southern textile plants to help workers achieve higher wages, health insurance and other benefits and to ensure fair labor practices. He was instrumental in unionizing J.P. Stevens, the historic campaign upon which the academy award winning movie "Norma Rae" was based. Scott is survived by his second wife Barbara; son and daughter-in-law Scott Hoyman and Alice Orzechowski; daughter and son-in-law Michele Hoyman and Michael Mackuen; son and partner Neal Grier Hoyman and Joan Hutchison; grandchildren Dr. Courteney Mackuen and Elan Hoyman. His first wife, Dotti, died in 2000. Scott will also be missed by the expansive community of Workers United (successor union to ACTWU). Noel Beasley, President of Workers United, stated: "Scott was a great leader, teacher and friend. His commitment to workers, their families and communities was focused, disciplined and effective." James Andrews, President of the North Carolina AFL-CIO, said: "He was committed to workers and workers' rights and particularly those earning low wages in textile plants in the south. It was a delight to work with Scott, who helped to ground me in organizing skills." Donations in his memory may be made to American Association of University Women Scholarship Fund, or Medical Outreach Clinic: aauw.org/get-involved/ or medicaloutreachclinic.org
